ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: No others
Seminar section after class
Combined with weekly virtual discussion.
live virtual section

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Pretty in-depth knowledge of modern Middle East history and events that shaped the region over the past 200 years
I learned how to analyze historical texts and historical contexts to reveal new knowledge.
Knowledge of the formation of the Modern Middle East. And practice close-reading and historical analysis.
I learned about the history of the modern Middle East, focusing on states such as the Ottoman Empire, Iran, and Egypt. I learned how to approach primary sources and respond to them critically.
An understanding of the historical currents that drove the development of the modern middle east and the context that underlies todays conflicts in the region.
I gained a information that now allows me a solid foundation for understanding long-standing historical issues in the Middle East.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I really loved all the readings and the discussion section especially. I also thought the lectures were really interesting. Would have liked a little more discussion in the lectures as well since the class was so small

Strengths - content was very informative 
Weaknesses - more of a lecture so it was difficult to understand how to analyze the historical context, though as an upper level course, most students should understand how to do so at a basis level

A strength of this course are the primary documents - on the whole, I found them interesting and they presented new information. I also think the format of the class (timelines, short quizzes, essays) greatly facilitated learning. I think lectures could be presented in a more engaging way though.
Very well organized for the most part, covered a lot of ground but never felt rushed, but sometimes regions didnt feel so connected
Professor Gledhill was a great instructor who really provided a structure for students to succeed in his class. Henry Clements was also a great TA for the course and really ensured great feedback.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I thought the discussion sections were still really interesting. The lectures were maybe slightly less engaging over Zoom than they would have been in person, but still pretty good.
Recorded lectures and the module listing in canvas. This class was the only one of mine that knew how to upload documents and files, which helped a lot.
It's affected, but still very good.
I appreciated that lectures and powerpoints were uploaded to Canvas! Also, having the documents available electronically was a great help
sections were very good, powerpoint lecture format with powerpoints and constant student participation, in-zoom polls followed by discussions to break up lecture worked really well
I think all in all, Professor Gledhill and Henry did a great job adapting this course to the pandemic.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! Professor Gledhill and Henry did such a good job leading this class. The material is super interesting and they presented it all in a very digestible way that made it easy to understand even though I didn't have a background in the Middle East.
Yes, you learn a lot about history and the professor cares.
Yes.
I would recommend this course to anyone interested in understanding a general history of the Middle Eastern region. There's quite a bit of reading, but it's manageable and usually interesting.

Great class for majors and nonmajors alike. If you want to understand the current political and societal conditions in the middle east, this is a great, digestable class. not too much work but you still learn a lot
Yes, I think anyone interested in the Middle East would find Gledhill's to be a great introduction to the history of the region.

HIST 380 01/MMES 379 01
        The Making of the Modern ME
